timeline.text:
This is a 62-year-old Hispanic male – let's call him Martin.


Martin is trying to sleep. But he's rolling around in bed, sleepless.

We know so much about Martin because he recorded everything he did for one day in 2021.¹ We know Martin doesn't have a wife or partner. He doesn't have children in his home. And he doesn't have a job. For someone in his 60s, these are potential red flags – because he could be missing something critical to human survival: social bonds. Many animals – especially humans – need social bonds. Humans evolved to survive in groups, whether that's gathering food or fighting off predators. When we don't have those connections, our bodies sound the alarm with a pain we now call loneliness. "Feelings of loneliness told them when those protective bonds were endangered or deﬁcient," wrote neuroscientist John Cacioppo. "What’s missing when you’re lonely is the feeling of closeness, trust, and the affection of genuine friends, loved ones, and community," writes former US surgeon general Vivek Murthy in his 2020 book, Together. "When we feel lonely, we’re unhappy and long to escape this emotional pain." Today's humans aren't being hunted by tigers, but strong and stable relationships are still a fundamental human need. Without those bonds, we feel more anxious, more fearful, and more stressed. After all, thousands of years of evolution has programmed us to believe that when we're isolated, we're in danger.
¹ He did it for the American Time Use Survey, which has tracked how Americans spend their time since 2003.
Martin got out of bed and is watching TV.

It looks like Martin is fine for now.


Let's take a look at some more people.

The average human knows about 5,000 faces. We can put a name to about 1,500 of them, and we personally know about 500.¹ But most of those people won't help us in times of need, nor will they make us feel less isolated. The people who will help are our friends – and psychologist Robin Dunbar argues that we have an average of 150 people who we try to contact at least once a year.² And within that group, he found that we have 50 people who contact once every six month; 15 people we contact once a month; five people we contact once a week; and one to two people with whom we share "really intense relationships like romantic partners." (Often, women also have this kind of relationship with their "Best Friend Forever.") >> DUNBAR CHART – BUT COLOR WITH SAME THING WE'LL USE BELOW
¹ According to facial recognition research by Rob Jenkins at the University of York
² Dunbar argues that an animal's brain size limits the number of stable relationships we can maintain, and for humans it is 150. Recent studies argue that there is no empirical evidence for this limit. We won't solve this argument in a footnote, so just imagine this group as people you'd want to invite to your wedding.
So let's code our friends and family with TKCOLOR and everyone else with TKCOLOR.

Everyone needs a different amount of social interaction. But according to the American Time Use Survey, the average American spends about 6 hours with friends or family each day. So let's track how many of these people interact with their friends or family for at least 6 hours a day. For the time spent with everyone else – acquaintances, coworkers, etc. – I'll count it as 40% as valuable as time spent with family and friends.¹ >> LEGEND ON SOCIAL INTERACTION
¹ This 2022 study of people's behavior during the Covid-19 pandemic hints that people feel about 40% as psychologically close to acquaintances as they to do friends. This is admittedly not the most robust way to give partial credit for non-friends and family, but I couldn't find anything better.
Martin came home from the grocery store and he's preparing lunch.
After lunch, he decided to watch TV again. He's been near other people today, like at the grocery store. But hasn't done anything with other people.

Lonely people report feeling more shy, more anxious, more negative, more angry, less optimistic, and having lower self esteem. But are they inherently different compared to everyone else? In a 2006 study, neuroscientist John Cacioppo and his colleagues hypnotized a bunch of college students to feel lonely. “Think of a time in which you felt isolated," they told the subjects. "You felt lonely. Perhaps you felt like you just didn’t belong—that you had no friends.” After confirming the hypnotism worked, they found that the students who were made to feel lonely reported the exact same negative feelings as people who were actually lonely. "We had demonstrated yet again that lonely individuals are not a breed apart," Cacioppo wrote in his book, Loneliness. "Any of us can succumb to loneliness, and along with it, all the other characteristics that travel as its entourage."

By now, you can see that many people are getting very little social interaction. Sure, this is just one day – but it's indicative of a growing problem in America: We're spending more time alone, and less time with friends and family. I analyzed the American Time Use Survey going back to 2003, and found that the amount of time we spend with family has drastically decreased across every age group: >> FAMILY CHART And the amount of time we spend with friends has plummeted: >> FRIENDS CHART Meanwhile, the amount of time we spend alone has gone up across every age group: >> AGE GROUP CHART Being alone isn't necessarily the same as being lonely. But according to a meta-analysis of studies, more people have reported feeling lonely every year since 1976. And then the pandemic supercharged our loneliness.
As you can see, most people have barely had TKTKT hours of interaction on this day – and this is a weekend day!

Every so often, the American Time Use Survey asks people a question that gets at how well someone is doing. It goes something like this:
Imagine a ladder. The top of the ladder is your best possible life. The bottom is your worst possible life. Which step of the ladder do you feel you personally stand at the present time?
This is now called the Cantril ladder, and in the US most people answer fairly positively – on average, people say they are a 7 out of 10. Pause for a second and ask yourself where you are on this ladder: >> CHART: CANTRIL LADDER
So let's sort everyone in this story by where they are on the Cantril ladder, from 0 to 10.

The day is almost over, and we can clearly see a trend.


People lower on the ladder are far more likely to have gone a full day being mostly isolated.

Loneliness affects everything about your life, and it robs us of our best selves. Isolated people are less generous with donations, less likely to persevere in the face of adversity, more likely to procrastinate, and more likely to administer harsher punishments.¹ They get lower quality sleep. And it may predict the progression of Alzheimer's disease. Ultimately, lonely people are 50% more likely to die prematurely than people with strong social connections – the equivalent of having six alcoholic drinks a day or smoking 15 cigarettes a day.
¹ From Cacioppo's book, Loneliness

Humans often ostracize others who are lonely. So when we are lonely, we hide it. We crawl deeper into our shells because we feel weak and vulnerable. When we're lonely, we become even more wary of social threats, so the very thing we need – social interaction – feels dangerous. We start to blame ourselves; we wonder if something really is wrong with us. "Over time," Murthy writes, "this vicious cycle may convince us we don’t matter to anyone and that we’re unworthy of love."

When I see large swaths of people saying they are living their worst possible life, and they fall asleep not knowing if anyone else in the world cares about them, something is clearly wrong – not with them, but with the world we've built.


We champion independence and self-sufficiency. If we don't have what we need – food, shelter, money – then we're told it's our damn fault.


We've created a world where millions of people feel the pain of isolation – a world that reminds them every day that they may not be worthy of love.

All of this is to say…


Maybe a top priority – for governments, for companies, for communities – should be to create a world where people feel worthy of love.
